awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:   Simulating Compositional and Structural Change in a Near Boreal Forest
awd_abstract_narration:
NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION
GEOGRAPHY SPATIAL SCIENCES (GSS) PROGRAM

ABSTRACT

This doctoral dissertation research will investigate the influences of competing factors such as climate conditions, land use, and fire that drive structural and compositional change in the near Boreal forests of the Upper Great Lakes region.  The research will provide an improved understanding of the response of vegetation to these impacts in order to promote long-term forest sustainability and resilience.  Enhanced forest landscape simulation modeling will provide new insights regarding vegetation and environmental dynamics, and a more holistic understanding of the impacts of disturbances on the ecosystem.  Outcomes from this research will provide land resources managers and stakeholders with potential future forest conditions scenarios enabling them to make informed, outcome-based environmental management decisions. Better management efforts will not only protect the ecosystem but also enhance recreational and economic activities in the region.  The project includes education and training opportunities for undergraduate students from underrepresented populations to enrich their research experiences.  As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

The near boreal forests of the Upper Great Lakes have undergone profound compositional, structural, and functional changes during the century following Euro-American settlement.  The historical dominance of red pine in the region is representative of fire's imprint on the landscape, however, 20th century land-use modification has generally excluded fire across the landscape, reducing dominance of resilient species and potentially increasing susceptibility of the regional forests to future environmental change.  The research supported by this award will focus on three core questions:  (1) Are there an adequate number lightning fires to maintain red pine stands in the Upper Great Lakes region? (2) How would the modern-day landscape composition and structure differ in the absence of 20th century landscape modification? (3) How will environmental changes influence fire regimes and subsequent vegetation patterns in the future?  The doctoral student will use the landscape disturbance and succession model, LANDIS-II to simulate forest compositional and structural change.  Four scenarios will be simulated, ranging temporally from pre-settlement times to AD 2300, to model forest changes in response to varying fire, climate, and land scenarios.

por.por_cntn:
This research sought to understand the spatial and temporal variability in historic fire events that occurred in the Border Lakes region of northern Minnesota. The study area consists of both Voyageurs National Park and the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness and encompasses about 417,900 ha of land. The landscape is naturally fragmented with forest patches interspersed with lakes and streams, totaling to over 110,900 ha or roughly 26.5% of the total area. Water acts as a natural break to fire, limiting the spread of fire events between forested stands. This research consisted of five objectives that evaluated how historic fire events co-occurred across the landscape. Objectives included: (1) determine the degree to which fire events are spatially synchronous; (2) evaluate the relationship between fire event synchrony and distance separating fire history locations; (3) assess temporal patterns in the fire regime that correspond to increased fire synchrony; (4) determine the mechanisms influencing variability in fire events; and  (5) evaluate how landscape structure, specifically area and isolation of islands, influence fire activity. Fire event synchrony is defined as fire events that co-occur in disjunct locations. Whereas fire asynchrony is defined as fire events that are isolated to one location and not found anywhere else in the study area. 

A total of 541 samples were collected within the Border Lakes region. Fire history was reconstructed with 217 fire years identified between 1489 and 2016. Samples were objectively grouped into 14 regions and the fire history was analyzed to evaluate the percentage of shared fire events between regions and the relationship to distance. Results indicate that historically fire occurrence was synchronous with 63% of the fires occurring in two or more of the 14 regions, 49% in three or more regions, and 29% of the fires recorded in four or more regions. However, the number of shared fire events between regions did not show a clear relationship with distance. These results suggest that fire events were spatially synchronous and landscape connectivity did not have a strong influence on the co-occurrence of fires at spatially disjunct locations.

Drought was a significant influence on synchronous fire events with both the fire event year and the year prior to the fire being significantly dry. While this result is important and furthers our understanding on the dynamics of larger, widespread fire events, asynchronous fire events were more likely to occur in cool, wet years. Asynchronous fire events in wetter conditions may be the result of several factors. First, wetter conditions may mean more convective producing storms and conditions may not promote fire spread (due to relatively high fuel moisture), yet smaller fires may ignite and burn. Second, asynchronous fire events could be the result of human ignitions either on purpose or accidental. Results further suggest human modification of the fire regime by regional variation in synchrony. For instance, two regions: Saganaga Lake and Central Lac La Croix, have evidence of human occupation between 1750 and 1900 and are both statistically different from all other regions in the occurrence of asynchronous fire events.

Area and isolation were evaluated as potential factors in influencing fire regimes on islands. We found that the area of islands are positively correlated with fire regime metrics including fire frequency, total number of fire events, and number of shared events between islands. In comparison, the isolation of islands was negatively correlated yet insignificant in influencing fire regime metrics. 

Overall, fire was historically frequent in the Border Lakes region of Minnesota with drought driving larger, synchronous fire events. Smaller, more isolated fire events were likely driven by human land use, specifically, indigenous groups located within the region. Results also indicate a strong shift from frequent fire prior to 1900 to few fire events after 1900. 

This project adds to a growing body of research being done on fire in northern Minnesota and reflects prior results on the legacy of fire in the region. This project has provided several opportunities for undergraduate involvement including, research development and fieldwork, data analysis, and research reporting. Results have been disseminated to academics and land managers, presented at conferences including the American Association of Geographers and the International Association of Landscape Ecology.
